body: Transfer 2 μg \(5 ml) of cleaved \(genomic) DNA to a silanized 1.5-ml microcentrifuge tube and chill for several minutes in an ice-water bath.

Prepare the first-strand synthesis mix that contains primer 1 and chill for several minutes in an ice-water bath.  Add 25 μl of this mix to the DNA sample, with gentle mixing with a pipette, and return the sample to the ice-water bath.  Place “lid-locks” on samples to prevent tubes from popping open during denaturation \(see Note 1).

Denature the DNA for 5 min at 95 °C; allow the primer to anneal for 30 min at 60 °C, and allow extension to proceed for 10 min at 76 °C.  As first-strand synthesis proceeds, prepare solutions for step 4 \(see Note 2).

Thaw 20 mM unidirectional linker mix in an ice-water bath.  Prepare the ligase dilution solution and prepare the partial ligase mix \(minus the unidirectional linker and T4 DNA ligase).  Chill both solutions in an ice-water bath \(see Note 23).

When the extension in step 3 is complete, immediately transfer the sample to the ice-water bath.  Microcentrifuge the tube briefly at 4 °C to collect any condensate and then return it to the ice-water bath \(see Note 4).
Finish preparing the ice-cold ligase mix mentioned in step 4 by adding the unidirectional linker mix, mixing, and adding T4 DNA ligase, in the ice-water bath \(see Note 5).

Add 20 μl of ice-cold ligase dilution solution from step 6 to the sample, mix gently with a pipette, and return to the ice-water bath.  Microcentrifuge the tube briefly at 4 °C and incubate overnight in a water bath at 16 °C \(see Note 6).
Prepare the sample for precipitation by placing in the ice-water bath for several minutes.  Microcentrifuge the tube briefly at 4 °C, then return to the ice-water bath \(see Note 7).

Prepare and chill the salt mix for precipitation.  Add 9.4 ml of ice-cold precipitation salt mix to the sample.  Then add 220 μl of ice-cold 100% ethanol.  Mix thoroughly by inversion and chill for more than 2 h at －20 °C.
Pellet the precipitate by mirocentrifugation for 15 min at 4 °C and discard supernatant.

Add 500 μl of room-temperature 75% ethanol and wash the pellet and walls of the tube.  Microcentrifuge the sample for 5 min at room temperature and discard the supernatant.  Remove the last traces of ethanol with a pipette and allow any remaining ethanol to evaporate by air drying or using a vacuum evaporator.

Add 70 μl of double-distilled H<sub>2</sub>O and allow sample to stand at room temperature to dissolve the pellet.  Agitate the tube occasionally to help the sample dissolve and, after each agitation, collect droplets by microcentrifugation for 2 to 3 sec.  When the pellet has dissolved \(usually within 30 min or less), chill the sample in an ice-water bath.  While the pellet is dissolving, prepare and chill the amplification mix that contains linker primer and primer
Add 13 μl of ice-cold amplification mix to the sample, mix gently with a pipette, and return the sample to the ice-water bath.
Add 3 μl \(1 U) of Vent DNA polymerase mix to the sample and mix carefully with a pipette.  Return the sample to the ice-water bath.
Cover the sample with 90 μl of mineral oil, microcentrifuge for a few seconds at 4 °C, and return to the ice-water bath.

Carry out 18 cycles of PCR, with the first denaturation for 3 to 4 min at 95 °C, and subsequent denaturations for 1 min.  Allow primers to anneal for 2 min at a temperature 0 to 2 °C above the calculated melting temperatures \(Tms);  if primer 2 and linker primer have different Tms, use the lower Tm.  Extend for 3 min at 76 °C.  Then, for every cycle, add an extra 5 sec to the extension step.  Allow final extension to proceed for 19 min.  Transfer the sample to the ice-water bath, remove the “lid-lock”  \(if applicable), and microcentrifuge briefly at 4 °C to collect any condensate.  Keep the sample in the ice-water bath \(see Note 8).

Prepare the end-labeling mix that contains radiolabeled primer 3 and chill for several minutes in the ice-water bath.  Add 5 μl of this mix to the sample.  Mix aqueous phases by gently pipetting them up and down, keeping the sample on ice as much as possible.  Microcentrifuge for a few seconds at 4 °C and return to the ice-water bath.

Carry out two rounds of PCR to label the DNA.  Perform the first denaturation for 3 to 4 min at 95 °C and the second for 1 min at 95 °C.  Anneal end-labeled primer 3 for 2 min at a temperature that is 0 to 2 °C above its calculate Tm.  Allow extension to proceed for 10 min at 76 °C.   When the second extension is complete, transfer the sample to the ice-water bath.

Place sample at room temperature and immediately add 295 μl of Vent DNA polymerase stop solution.  Mix on the vortex mixer.  Microcentrifuge the tube for a few seconds to collect radioactive droplets from the top and sides of the tube.  Add 500 μl of the mixture of phenol, chloform and isoamyl alcohol and mix either by vigorous shaking or on a vortex mixer.  Microcentrifuge for 3 to 5 min at room temperature.  Transfer the upper aqueous layer \(~ 400 μl; avoid the interface, if any) to a clean, silanized 1.5-ml microcentrifuge tube and mix thoroughly.  Microcentrifuge briefly to collect droplets from the sides of the tube.

Set up four clear, siliconized 1.5-ml microcentrifuge tubes and add 235 μl of room-temperature 100% ethanol to each tube.  Transfer 94 μl of the aqueous layer into each tube and mix thoroughly on the vortex mixer.  Then chill for 22 h at －20 °C.  Discard any remaining aqueous layer.
Microcentrifuge the chilled samples for 15 min at 4 °C and discard supernatants.

Add 500 μl of room-temperature 75% ethanol to each tube, mix on a vortex mixer, microcentrifuge samples for 5 min at room temperature, and discard supernatants.  Remove the last traces of ethanol with a pipette and allow any remaining ethanol to evaporate by air-drying or by using a vacuum evaporator.
Add 7 μl of loading buffer to each tube and allow tubes to stand at room temperature while pellets are dissolving.

Denature samples for 5 min at 85 °C to 90 °C.  Load the entire contents of each tube on a 6% sequencing gel.  After electrophoresis, fix and dry the gel, then autoradiograph the gel for 6 to 24 h without an intensifying screen.
As a control for LMPCR, prepare genomic DNA for LMPCR-aided direct genomic sequencing and sequence the DNA by chemical methods, as described elsewhere<sup>1-5</sup>.
Fix, for example, F9 cells \(1 x 10<sup>7</sup>), which have been stably transfected with either pcDNA or wild-type JDP2-encoding plasmids, with 1.1% formaldehyde for 30 min at room temperature.
Harvest cells and prepare mononucleosomes as described above.
In some cases, permeabilize F9 cells<sup>2</sup> and digest partially with micrococcal nuclease \(MNase; at 30 U, 15 U, 7.5 U and 0 U per reaction mixture), and then purify genomic DNA.
Perform cleavage mapping of MNase-digested DNA by Southern blotting analysis using a \[<sup>32</sup>P]-labeled DRE oligonucleotide as probe.
Purify mononucleosomal DNA with a gel extraction kit \(Qiagen GmbH; Hilden, Germany) according to the protocol from the manufacturer, with subsequent primer extension.
Perform the primer extension reaction as described above.
To demonstarate our method, we used the adapters LMPCR-1 and LMPCR-2 \(see above for sequences).

Ligation to the extension product was allowed to proceed for 16 h at 16 ˚C and was followed by PCR with gene-specific primers 2 or 3 \(see above for sequences) and the top-strand adaptor primer \(LMPCR-1).
The extended products were fractionated on a sequencing gel \(6% acrylamide) beside with DNA sequencing reactions that provided size markers \(see Figure 5).
